questions.text: Give the correct sequencing of the pathophysiology of hepatorenal syndrome. Renal vasoconstriction Systemic vasodilation Vasopressin release Cytokine release
questions.explanation:
Hepatorenal syndrome

Definition

Acute kidney injury in advanced liver disease

Pathophysiology

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of hepatorenal syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Jaundice which begins in the sclera

questions.correct_answer: A. Stepwise decrease in serum creatinine
questions.explanation:
Fatigue and lethargy

Initial symptoms

Loss of appetite

Due to increasing nausea

Jaundice

Begins in the sclera and progresses from head-to-toe. (Option B ruled out)

Coagulopathy

Impaired liver synthetic function, increasing the risk of bleeding. (Option D ruled out)

Ascites

Slow, gradual buildup of fluid in the peritoneum due to intravascular loss of albumin.

Hepatic encephalopathy

Confusion and altered mental status (Option C ruled out) as the liver fails to metabolize toxins.

Oliguria

Progressive decrease in urination frequency and volume as renal function deteriorates.

Creatinine

Stepwise progressive increase in creatinine (Option A)

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with worsening ascites, oliguria, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals tense ascites, mild jaundice, and peripheral edema. Laboratory investigations show: Serum creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL (baseline: 0.9 mg/dL) Serum sodium: 126 mEq/L Urine sodium: <10 mEq/L Albumin infusion is planned as part of his management. What is the recommended dosage of albumin infusion for this patient?
questions.explanation:
• Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Type 1 hepatorenal syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Doubling of serum creatinine over 2 weeks

questions.explanation:
Type 1 HRS

Type 2 HRS

 
  • Doubling of the serum creatinine to at least greater than 2.5 or a decrease in the creatinine clearance by half or more over a two-week period. (Option A ruled out)
  • Urine output of less than 500mL/day (Option B ruled out)
  • Normal urine sediment (Option C ruled out)
  • Low urinary sodium excretion (Option D)
  
  • Stable
  • Better prognosis
  • Less severe kidney injury
  • Diuretic-resistant ascites

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a long history of cirrhosis presents to the clinic with worsening shortness of breath over the past few months. He reports that his breathlessness worsens when standing and improves when lying down. Physical examination reveals spider angiomas. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. A contrast-enhanced echocardiogram (bubble study) is performed, and delayed bubbles are seen in the left atrium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features
  • Characterised by the triad of:
    • Liver disease
    • Intrapulmonary vascular dilatation
    • Arterial hypoxemia
  • PaO2 less than 80 mm Hg while breathing in room air.
  • Platypnoea: Worsening of dyspnea when moving from a supine to an upright position.
  • Orthodeoxia: Decrease in PaO2 of more than 5% or more than 4 mm Hg when moving from supine to upright.
  • Portal hypertension
  • Diffuse telangiectasia/Spider naevi
  • Cyanosis
  • Fatigue and clubbing

Complications
  • Refractory hepatopulmonary syndrome.
  • Severe post-transplant hypoxemia.
  • Post-transplant portopulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes intrapulmonary shunting?
questions.explanation:
Etiopathogenesis

HPS is most commonly associated with chronic liver disease or cirrhosis.

  • Liver disease: Chronic liver conditions like cirrhosis trigger systemic inflammation, releasing vasodilatory substances.
  • Nitric oxide (NO) and other vasodilators: increased NO causes intrapulmonary vascular dilatation. These dilated vessels result in abnormal oxygenation as blood bypasses the alveoli without adequate gas exchange, leading to shunt-like physiology.
  • Imbalance in angiogenic factors: Dysregulation of vascular growth factors such as endothelin-1 and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) promotes abnormal vascular remodeling in the lungs.
  • Ventilation-perfusion mismatch: The dilated pulmonary vessels result in a mismatch between areas of ventilation and blood flow, reducing the lung’s ability to oxygenate blood efficiently.

Clinical Features
  • Characterised by a triad of:
    • Liver disease
    • Intrapulmonary vascular dilatation
    • Arterial hypoxemia
  • PaO2 less than 80 mm Hg while breathing in room air.
  • Platypnoea: Worsening of dyspnea when moving from a supine to an upright position.
  • Orthodeoxia: Decrease in PaO2 of more than 5% or more than 4 mm Hg when moving from supine to upright.
  • Portal hypertension
  • Diffuse telangiectasia/Spider naevi
  • Cyanosis
  • Fatigue and clubbing

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presents with worsening dyspnea.Physical examination reveals clubbing and cyanosis, which worsen when the patient sits upright and decrease in oxygen saturation when the patient changes position from supine to upright.Which of the following is considered the gold standard diagnostic method for confirming this condition?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG): Demonstrates hypoxemia with a low partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂).
  • Contrast-enhanced echocardiography (bubble study): Gold standard for diagnosing intrapulmonary vascular dilatations. Bubbles from injected saline will bypass the lung's capillaries and appear in the left atrium after a delay (delayed bubbles).
  • Pulmonary angiography: Diagnose and distinguish type I and type II HPS.
  • 99mTc-labeled macroaggregated albumin scan: Can show intrapulmonary shunting where labeled particles bypass the lungs and accumulate in systemic organs such as the brain or kidneys.
  • Chest X-ray or CT scan
  • Transesophageal Echocardiogram
  • Pulmonary function tests

Differential diagnoses
  • Portopulmonary hypertension
  • Atelectasis
  • Recurrent pulmonary emboli
  • Atrial septal defect
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Pneumonia

Treatment
  • Liver transplantation: The definitive treatment, as it addresses the underlying liver disease. It has been shown to reverse pulmonary vascular abnormalities and improve oxygenation over time.
  • Oxygen therapy: Supplemental oxygen can help manage hypoxemia but is only symptomatic relief.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): This procedure is used to reduce portal hypertension.
  • Pulmonary arterial coil embolization
  • No medical therapy approved for HPS.

Complications
  • Refractory hepatopulmonary syndrome.
  • Severe post-transplant hypoxemia.
  • Post-transplant portopulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings does not typically indicate alcoholic hepatitis?

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to 50 U/L - 400 U/L

options.label: C
options.text: AST:ALT (alanine aminotransferase) ratio of more than 1.5

options.label: D
options.text: Absolute value of AST/ALT greater than 600 U/L

questions.correct_answer: D. Absolute value of AST/ALT greater than 600 U/L

questions.text: What amount of alcohol consumption is generally considered to significantly increase the risk of developing alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.correct_answer: D. More than 100 grams per day
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Mild Alcoholic Hepatitis

Minimal liver inflammation with few symptoms.Mild elevation of liver enzymes.

Moderate Alcoholic Hepatitis

Increased liver inflammation with symptoms such as jaundice, abdominal pain and elevated liver enzymes.

Severe Alcoholic Hepatitis

Significant inflammation, liver failure, and complications like coagulopathy, ascites, and encephalopathy.

Cirrhosis

Long-term consequence of repeated episodes of alcoholic hepatitis leading to irreversible liver damage and scarring (cirrhosis).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of heavy alcohol consumption presents with jaundice, abdominal pain, and fatigue. A liver biopsy is performed to assess the extent of liver damage. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of this condition? Histopathology image given below:
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Metabolism
  • Ethanol is primarily metabolized in the liver by enzymes, particularly alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1).
  • This metabolism produces acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate, which can cause cellular damage.

Oxidative Stress
  • The metabolism of alcohol generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increases oxidative stress within liver cells.
  • This oxidative damage leads to lipid peroxidation, protein modifications, and DNA damage, contributing to hepatocyte injury and inflammation.

Inflammatory Response
  • Alcohol consumption stimulates the activation of immune cells (e.g., Kupffer cells) leading to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6).
  • These cytokines promote inflammation and can further damage hepatocytes.

Altered Lipid Metabolism
  • Alcohol disrupts normal lipid metabolism, leading to fat accumulation in liver cells (steatosis).
  • This accumulation can progress to steatohepatitis, where inflammation and liver cell injury occur.

Fibrosis and Cirrhosis
  • Chronic inflammation and injury stimulate the activation of hepatic stellate cells, which produce collagen and lead to fibrosis.
  • Over time, repeated injury can result in cirrhosis, characterized by scarring and loss of normal liver architecture.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents with jaundice and altered sensorium. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin, AST > ALT, hypoalbuminemia, and prolonged PT/INR. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of the presence of hepatic encephalopathy in this patient?
questions.explanation:
General
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Fever, malaise, jaundice, history of alcohol intake + (at least within last 8 weeks before symptom onset)

Abdominal
  • Right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites
  • Caput medusae: enlarged veins radiating from the umbilicus
  • Bleeding varices (portal hypertension)

Dermatological
  • Spider angioma, palmar erythema, ecchymosis

Reproductive
  • Gynaecomastia, gonadal atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea

Neurological
  • Peripheral neuropathy: tingling and numbness usually over feet
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Ophthalmoplegia, confusion, ataxia + anterograde amnesia
  • Hepatic encephalopathy: Asterixis (most prominent finding), altered sensorium, sleep disturbances, lethargy

Others
  • Dupuytren’s contracture, temporal muscle wasting, parotid gland enlargement

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a long history of heavy alcohol use presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal distension. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, spider angiomas, and ascites. What is the most specific investigation to diagnose his condition?
questions.explanation:
AST (Aspartate aminotransferase)

Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)

ALT (Alanine aminotransferase)

Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient succumbed to death, history revealed that the patient was admitted for liver failure 1 week back. Biopsy done is as shown below. What type of inclusions are seen in the biopsy, and what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Liver function tests (LFT)
  • AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1: Most specific for ALD
  • GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase): Non-specific marker of ALD
  • S.Bilirubin: Usually normal/mildly ↑

USG
  • Increased liver span, altered echotexture
  • Reversal seen in portal venous flow (Portal hypertension)

Coagulation profile
  • PT/INR: Elevated
  • (All coagulation factors are synthesized in liver except factor-VIII)

RFT
  • S.Creatinine: May be elevated in later stages (Hepato-renal syndrome)

Biopsy findings
  • Neutrophils infiltration with ballooned hepatocytes
  • Malory-Denk bodies: Intracytoplasmic hyaline inclusions
  • Bilirubin Stasis & ductular reaction
  • Chicken wire fibrosis (later stages)

questions.text: Which among the following are components of the MELD 3.0 score? 1) Male sex 2) Albumin 3) Creatinine 4) AST 5) INR 6) Serum Na+
questions.explanation:
MELD: (Model of End-stage Liver Disease)
  • Creatinine (3)
  • Bilirubin
  • INR (5)

MELD 3.0 :

  • Female sex
  • S. Bilirubin
  • S. Albumin (2)
  • S.Sodium (6)
  • INR
  • S.Creatinine

(mnemonic: FBASIC)

Maddrey’s Discriminant function

4.6 (PTPATIENT - PTCONTROL) + S.bilirubin

Glasgow Alcoholic Hepatitis score
  • Age
  • WBC count
  • BUN (Blood urea nitrogen)
  • S. Bilirubin
  • INR

Indications to start treatment for ALD:
  • MELD ≥ 21
  • Discriminant function ≥ 32

questions.text: A female patient who is a known alcoholic presented to OPD with jaundice and malaise. Her initial reports were PT: 24 sec (N: 11-14sec); AST: 70 Units/L (N: 10-40 U/L) ; ALT: 70 Units/L (N: 8-55 U/L); Bilirubin: 2 mg/dL (N: 0.2-1.3 mg/dL). What is the preferred management of choice?
questions.explanation:
Steatosis

(DF < 32 & MELD < 21)

Only lifestyle modifications:

  • Alcohol abstinence
  • Dietary changes

Steato-Hepatitis

(DF ≥ 32 / MELD ≥ 21)
  • Oral Prednisolone 32 mg/day for 4 weeks
  • Check S.Bilirubin levels 1 week after starting steroids
  • Other drugs: N-acetyl cysteine, Pentoxifylline, anti-TNFα agents

Cirrhosis (Organ failure/ Portal hypertension)
  • Liver transplant

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of Liver FibroTest?
questions.explanation:
Method

Parameters

Cirrhosis

APRI (AST to platelet Ratio Index)
  • AST, Platelet count

> 1.5

ELF (Enhanced Liver Fibrosis)
  • Age
  • Hyaluronic acid
  • MMP-3 (Metalloproteinase)
  • TIMP (Tissue Inhibitor of Metalloproteinase)

> 9.3

FIB – 4
  • Age, AST, ALT, platelet count

> 3.25

FibroTest
  • Haptoglobin (Option A)
  • α2- macroglobulin
  • Apolipoprotein A1
  • γ-GT (GGT) (Option C)
  • Total bilirubin (Option D)

> 0.63

TE (Transient Elastography/ Fibrosure/ Fibroscan)
  • Wave speed generated by vibration through liver tissue is measured

> 8 kPa (Fibrosis)

> 12.5 kPa (Cirrhosis)

ARFT [Acoustic Radiation force imaging]
  • Wave speed generated by acoustic radiation through liver tissue is measured

> 1.87 m/s

Forn index

Platelet count, GGT, Age, Cholesterol

  • Forn Index = 7.811 − (3.131 × log (Platelets)) + (0.781 × log (GGT)) + (3.467 × log (Age)) − (0.014×Cholesterol)
  • Interpretation:
    • Low Forn Index (<4.2): Low probability of significant fibrosis.
    • High Forn Index (≥4.2): High probability of significant fibrosis or cirrhosis.

>4.2
